title: Before 1 October 2021, will the Republic of Chad announce that legislative elections currently scheduled for 24 October 2021 will be postponed or canceled?
preds:
With Deby dead and his son taking over and protests, there’s no way they are going to hold any elections this year while those in power scramble to make a place for themselves.  It’s more likely to dissolve into a civil war than go for an election.
https://africanarguments.org/2021/04/chad-france-firmly-backs-continuity-but-will-the-people/
https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/real-threat-chads-military-rulers-unemployed-youth-2021-04-30/ https://www.theafricareport.com/79552/chad-will-the-11-april-presidential-election-be-idriss-deby-itnos-final-one/
Article from before the announcement of the death, but shows the next generation are already entrenched and running things behind the scenes.  Now will be time for them to consolidate.  An election looks a bit too dangerous for them at this stage.  They can use the violence and protests as an excuse. Unless we get a surprise and they decide to make the country more democratic, but that seems unlikely.  Only reason not going for 100pc.

"The new PM told journalists in the Chadian capital Ndjamena that he is determined to ensure that citizens lay the foundation for a great national consensus so that *at the end of the transition*, a free and transparent election can be held.
[...]
The junta that dissolved parliament and suspended the country's constitution said it will rule for 18 months at the end of which an election will be organised."
https://allafrica.com/stories/202104280099.html
There is a transition government in place with the backing of the armed forces so there will probably be no push for elections

After the death of Debey, and the move to a transition government, I don't see a way to organize and hold legislative elections before 24 October.  The current military council has said another 18 months.

Transition government seems very much like a coup, or at the very least a way to force an election which will produce the desired outcome of the transition government. Though there's a chance they actually aim to do good here, or at least, the appearance of doing good, and thus hold elections. Track record for these kinds of governments though are usually towards keeping the power themselves in some way or shape.

I agree with other commenters that the 18 months of military rulership probably imply no parliamentary elections. However, I'm surprised that rebel groups actually managed to kill Déby; I imagine that they feel strong right now.

Convinced by the crowd and additional info that Kaka will be granted an 18 month interim rulership, probably unconditional with respect to further elections. The people of Chad must have gotten used to it already.
The heir apparent will have full international support, since nobody wants another flash point in Central Africa, besides the already existing ones in Libya, Mali, Ethiopia, DRC,... As a general, he's likely the right man to handle the Chadian army in France's and Europe's favor. EDIT:
Germany asked all German citizens to leave the country immediately and warns of unforeseeable conditions, deteriorating security.
https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/aussenpolitik/laender/tschad-node/tschadsicherheit/225774
Agree with others that Deby's death means legislative elections will be postponed.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-56815708
Seems like a fairly drastic way to avoid elections, but the October ones are right out.  The story says, "A military council led by Mr Déby's son, a 37-year-old four star general, will govern for the next 18 months.”   The folks in Chad will probably be spared the burden of elections for quite a long time, since General Kid will undoubtedly wish to carry on his daddy's legacy for a couple of decades.

Deby dead and son takes charge https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/apr/20/chad-president-idriss-deby-dies-military-says
Good time to postpone elections?

Before:
https://www.dw.com/en/chad-president-deby-wins-reelection-extending-30-years-in-power/a-57258862 After:
https://www.thecitizen.co.tz/tanzania/news/africa/chad-s-president-deby-dies-hours-after-winning-sixth-term-3369506
"Aljazeera reports that General Mahamat Kaka, the son of late Deby has been named interim head of State."
https://www.ktpress.rw/2021/04/chad-president-idriss-deby-dies/

Chad’s Deby takes early election lead as rebels near Ndjamena - Al Jazeera English
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/18/chads-deby-takes-early-election-lead-as-rebels-near
Sun, 18 Apr 2021 05:00:44 GMT Chad Holds Another Sham Election - Council on Foreign Relations
https://www.cfr.org/blog/chad-holds-another-sham-election
Tue, 13 Apr 2021 20:02:56 GMT What a surprise /s > “Until midday, the polling stations were almost empty in almost all towns in the country but CENI has just concocted fictitious results to deceive Chadians,” Yacine Abderaman Sakine, the head of the opposition Reform Party, told the Reuters news agency on Saturday.
> “We do not recognise this result.”

https://apnews.com/article/travel-politics-africa-chad-ff9e3eaf4ed7398d61c7d260f5abbcce
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/18/chads-deby-takes-early-election-lead-as-rebels-near The vote count may be suspended.  Whether it is or not, Deby will announce that he has won the election, and then promptly declare that the situation is too dangerous to have any more elections for a while.  He is very concerned for the well-being of his people, who are deeply grateful for his solicitude.   (Strange turn of phrase by the opposition guy at the end of the al-Jazeera story:  "We do not recognize this result."  Most of us immediately recognize a smashing victory in a crooked election.  Few political phenomena are more universally recognized, I'll betcha.)

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/11/voters-in-chad-head-to-polls-as-leader-debby-seeks-sixth-terms This could now go either way:  The freshly re-anointed President For Life could let the National Assembly get elected, since everybody from the opposition is or will be jailed or buried; or he could announce that things are so dire that he must regretfully dispense with the niceties for a while longer.   My money, if I had any, would be on the latter.  Elections are a great bother and distraction, and can occasionally surprise.  Guys like Deby hate surprises.

No change in the last two weeks. COVID cases continue to rise, which is a handy excuse. Not sure if they will linger through October, but they are impacting infrastructure and migration. So if Deby felt the need to switch up reasons for delayed elections, he’s got a couple ready to go.
What is the incentive not to?
Whoops - legislative elections have been repeatedly postponed since 2015.

https://www.africanews.com/2021/03/14/chad-president-kicks-off-campaign-for-sixth-term/ I've decided to go against the crowd here. Deby knows he's going to win. So why would he postpone it knowing that he can just rig the results?
No change. Going slightly up towards the crowd.
The circumstances have not changed for the better since the last time.

Deby just launched his campaign for a sixth term, and is widely recognized as a"shoo-in". Again, I don't think there is any reason for him to rush legislative elections, especially when using COVID as an excuse to continue to postpone. https://www.africanews.com/2021/03/14/chad-president-kicks-off-campaign-for-sixth-term/

Presidential election due in next few weeks looks to be following the usual line of get rid of the opposition.  If the presidential elections go well they may be emboldened to go forward with the parliamentary elections to shore up that result.  But all indications from the past 10 years are that they have been trying to avoid parliamentary elections, so think they are likely to be put off again.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Chadian_parliamentary_election
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/3/1/chad-opposition-leader-quits-presidential-race-after-shootout
Going with crowd forecast here: they've repeatedly postponed them. Why change it now when Deby wants to keep his grip on power? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Chadian_parliamentary_election
Parliamentary elections are scheduled to be held in Chad on Sunday, 24 October 2021.

Deby is running for a sixth term in April, and the opposition just quit.  Not looking good for presidential or legislative elections.  There will be no condemnation from the US or other Western countries as long as Chad continues to support the War on Terror.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/2/6/chad-police-confront-protesters-as-deby-nominated-for-sixth-term
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/3/1/chad-opposition-leader-quits-presidential-race-after-shootout
https://www.justsecurity.org/72318/chads-counterterrorism-support-abroad-drives-repression-and-discontent-at-home/
It’s a fifty fifty split, on the outcome

There are few incentives, real or imagined for the incumbent government to expend resources on a democratic exercise that will focus attention on legislative and executive failure at a time when the pandemic will have impacted incomes.
-5% to -10% adjustment downwards from Laplace's rule. (s+1)/(n+1). Intuitively, I'd expect them to want the legitimacy which comes from at least staging elections.

On the basis that after 5 postponements, there appears to be no reason why Deby should go ahead with these elections, especially as if they have any funds they will surely have to be used for a vaccine rollout (ready-made excuse) but handicapping my answer due to lack of knowledge around the various possibilities.
Presidential election first, results from that may change liklihood
History and culture of the region has not been forgotten by the generational families of the area.  They don’t subscribe to contemporary liberal institutions. And probably never will.
COVID is the perfect excuse to hold them back again (I don't think the vaccine will be available for the majority of the population then)
Won't be covid vaccination for them yet so it will be the perfect excuse.
5 time the election has been pushed back, not this time they saw the U.S. Insurrection.

Based on historical trends, there is zero incentive for Chad to hold elections on time (or at all).  The last three rounds of elections were concluded as fraudulent by outside bodies. There was no opposition participation in the last elections (boycotted), which undermines the election results even further.  There were a couple of articles (one cited below) that point out that Chad is one of the strongest militaries in the region, and highly competent in supporting countries like France conducting counter-terrorism ops in the Sahel.  Because some Western countries rely on that stability (regardless of who is running the country), they are unlikely to raise the issue and just maintain the status quo.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Chad
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1918-before-1-october-2021-will-the-republic-of-chad-announce-that-legislative-elections-currently-scheduled-for-24-october-2021-will-be-postponed-or-canceled
Walking up from 80% because maybe i am being too hopeful of a coherent africa policy by State dept.

The pandemic has already been a reason for postponement (when there were only about 20 cases/day, source: https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19). The projected incidence of the virus for October 2021 in Chad suggests that a further postponement is possible for the same reason.
There is currently no political pressure from other states to my knowledge to incite these elections.

Currently, the general election aftermath in neighboring Central African Republic (C.A.R.) is a dissuasive example.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_Central_African_general_election
"On 25 December, two days before the elections, unidentified armed gunmen attacked national security forces and international peacekeepers serving with the UN peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic in Dékoa, central Kémo Prefecture, and Bakouma, southern Mbomou Prefecture. Three Burundian peacekeepers were killed and an additional two were wounded. The attack occurred hours after a rebel coalition fighting the government called off a unilateral truce and reiterated calls for the suspension of the election.[...]
During the first round, voting was unable to take place in 29 of the 71 sub-prefectures according to Augustin Yangana-Yahote, the Minister for Territorial Administration. Six others only managed to partially vote before being shut down due to voter intimidation.Observers noted possible irregularities in the conduct of the election. An observer group reported that a large number of voters cast ballots with letters of exemption in Bangui. The procedure allows voters to cast their ballot elsewhere than the polling station where they are registered. According to the Rainbow Network, 81 percent of the votes were cast in this manner."
Faustin-Archange Touadéra has been voted president in the first round due to a slim 53% majority, which is however obviously the intended result of massive irregularities.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_Central_African_general_election#Conduct "Fighting between rebel groups and the CAR's national army has continued around the country since the election. The rebels declared an intent to take the war to Bangui, but a combination of the army, UN peacekeepers and Russian troops have prevented them from doing so."
Even though an outright war could be prevented so far, the massive outbreak of violence has caused 100,000 persons to be displaced (with about 2m or roughly half of the population suffering from decades-long unrest anyway), international organizations already speak of a large-scale humanitarian crisis looming.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_Central_African_general_election#Reactions_and_aftermath Chad shares a 1,554km border with the C.A.R., which has a longer border only with the Democratic Republic of the Congo (1,747km).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geography_of_the_Central_African_Republic It appears likely that the conflict in the C.A.R. also affects Chad's interior affairs, by border crossing of C.A.R.'s refugees, impact on trade and availability of food staples, ethnic conflicts imported, similar allegations of attempted vote rigging by the C.A.R.'s blueprint, and even outbreaks of violence before, during, and after the scheduled election. Sticking to the election date during this civil war-like circumstance in C.A.R. appears to be irresponsible, unrealistic and even provocative. UN peacekeeping missions, I imagine, will do everything in their power to prevent a similar situation in Chad in the making, and will try to influence decision makers to suspend the election indefinitely.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chadian_Civil_War_(2005%E2%80%932010) The 2021 Chadian presidential election, scheduled for 01 [EDIT:11] April 2021, could be a good indicator of whether any election in Chad will be canceled due to CoViD-19, however, the 2021 presidential election is widely seen as a formal farce intended to elect the incumbent Idriss Déby, who "presided over the removal of constitutional limits to his rule", for a sixth term in office. If they get cancelled, the legislative elections will get cancelled for sure.
https://qz.com/africa/1957067/the-african-elections-to-watch-in-2021-uganda-ethiopia-zambia/
Being a "largely ceremonial affair given the highly limited space for the political opposition to operate", the 2021 presidential election will likely take place imho and, given their potential to stain the president's election results afterwards if there is cringily little voter turnout or support for the president's "string-puppets" in the 2021 legislative elections, it is rather the latter one that I'd expect not to take place in 2021. There's very little information to find about these, however.
https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2021-elections/#chad
https://www.eisa.org/pubChad.php
https://www.eisa.org/jae19-2.php [...none...]

Between COVID-19 and armed jihadist groups it is likely that Chad will postpone or cancel the elections. The United States has more pressing issues to focus on in the Middle East and East Asia while France's attention is drawn primarily to Mali right now. Without external pressure it is unlikely that these elections will occur on schedule.

I am of two minds. The last postponement was due to covid. So covid will still be around in september which supports postponement. On the other hand, Trump did not care about these minor things, but Biden might.  So Biden may talk to Macron to pressure Deby to allow the election to proceed for the sake of image. They held elections up to 2011. But then again the election result is not in doubt so why spend the money.  Start at 80 and prbably walk it up to 100 over time.

Cancelling or postponing elections is all the rage these days.   Corrupt regimes have always been especially fond of this ploy, and there are few more corrupt than the lot in Chad.  After I think about this a little more and make some phone calls ("phone calls" are sort of like texts, only with voice--ask your parents), I'll probably come up more, but you gotta start someplace.
